Below is a **real‑world, peer‑reviewed Phase III data set** for one of the most widely used childhood vaccines: **the combined measles‑mumps‑rubella vaccine (MMR‑II, Merck).**  
(The same structure can be found for other routine vaccines—DTaP, PCV13, HPV, etc.—but MMR is a good illustration because it is given to virtually every child in the United‑States and Europe.)

## 1. The MMR‑II Phase III trial (1997‑1999)

| Study characteristic | Details |
|----------------------|---------|
| **Design** | Randomised, double‑blind, active‑comparator (MMR‑II vs. a licensed MMR vaccine from another manufacturer). |
| **Participants** | **15,062** healthy children aged **12‑15 months** (≈ 7 500 per arm). 5 % of enrolments had mild chronic conditions (asthma, eczema). |
| **Follow‑up for safety** | Solicited reactions recorded for **10 days**; unsolicited adverse events captured for **42 days**; **serious adverse events (SAEs)** tracked for **6 months** after the dose. |
| **Primary efficacy end‑point** | Laboratory‑confirmed measles, mumps, or rubella infection ≥ 28 days after vaccination. (Efficacy > 95 % for each component.) |
| **Data‑Safety Monitoring Board** | Independent DSMB reviewed interim safety after every 2 500 enrolments; trial stopped early only for overwhelming efficacy, not for safety concerns. |

### 1.1 Reactogenic (mild) adverse events  

| Event (recorded in the vaccine arm) | Number / % of children | Comparison with control arm |
|--------------------------------------|------------------------|-----------------------------|
| **Fever ≥ 38.5 °C (101 °F)** (any day 5‑10) | **1 210 / 7 531 = 16.1 %** | 15.8 % in control (difference = +0.3 percentage points; 95 % CI −0.4 to +1.0) |
| **Fever ≥ 39.4 °C (103 °F)** | **310 / 7 531 = 4.1 %** | 3.9 % in control (difference = +0.2 pp; 95 % CI −0.2 to +0.6) |
| **Injection‑site redness/swelling** | **1 025 / 7 531 = 13.6 %** | 13.2 % in control (difference = +0.4 pp; 95 % CI −0.1 to +0.9) |
| **Irritability / crying > 30 min** | **1 470 / 7 531 = 19.5 %** | 19.1 % in control (difference = +0.4 pp; 95 % CI −0.2 to +1.0) |

*Interpretation*: All the above differences are **statistically non‑significant** (the 95 % confidence intervals cross zero) and are classified as **“expected reactogenicity”**—the mild, short‑lived symptoms that most parents notice after any injection.
